items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively monitoring river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid contact with flood water and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Further light rainfall is forecast over today. 

We continue to monitor the situation. 

Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and remain safe and aware of your local surroundings.

River levels are high but steady at the Warwick river gauge as a result of rainfall and snow melt.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Avon between Rugby and Bidford including Warwick, Stratford upon Avon, caravan parks and farmland.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high into Sunday, 12/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 17:00 on 11/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Dernford river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property/roads and farmland is possible today, 11/03/23. Flooding is affecting River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach.
 
Further light rain is forecast for the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

This message will be updated this afternoon, 11/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high throughout today 11/03/23. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 17:00 this afternoon, 11/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: East Sussex, Kent, Surrey, West Sussex

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.. 

We continue to monitor the situation and will re issue any alerts or warnings if required.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the River Wey as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of footpaths and farmland is possible over today 11/03/23, especially in the Godalming and Bordon areas. Levels started to rise earlier in the week due to the heavy rainfall after a drier period and are expected to continue to respond to the showers particularly on the Hell Ditch. 
Further light rainfall is forecast over today. We expect river levels to begin to fall over the weekend.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 11/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. The forecast this morning is dry, with some outbreaks of rain this evening and overnight. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Evesham river gauge.  Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Avon from Abbotts Salford to Tewkesbury. Other locations that may be affected include Offenham, Evesham, Twyning and the Eckington Road. Predicted peaks:-  Bredon 1.6m to 1.8m this morning.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours which may cause further rises in river levels. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated  by 17:00 today,  11/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Castle Farm river gauge as a result of rainfall and snow melt.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Blythe between Cheswick Green and Blyth End.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours but we expect river levels to begin falling this morning, Saturday 11/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 17:00 on 11/03/23, or as the situation changes.

The River Ouse remains high but is now slowly falling, following more than half a month's rain (35mm) being recorded at Barcombe since Wednesday. It is possible that minor flood impacts will continue to affect rural roads, including Sloop Lane, Fletching Mill Bridge, Sharpsbridge and Barcombe Mills road until late Friday evening. Only isolated showers are forecast this weekend, which will allow the river to fall towards a more normal level by Saturday 11/03/2023. Further persistent and heavy rain is forecast for Sunday evening 12/03/2023 and through Monday 13/03/2023. River levels are expected to rise again Monday 13/03/2023 and flood impacts could return. We will reissue this message if confidence in the risk of flooding returning increases.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Eathorpe river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall and snow melt.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 17:00 on 11/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen on the River Ray as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and farmland is possible especially in the Lower Arncott and Islip areas. 
The forecast this morning is dry, with some outbreaks of rain this evening and overnight. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area clearing weed/trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 11/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Besford Bridge river gauge.  Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Brooks from Webheath to Defford. Other locations that may be affected include Crowle, Wickenham, Peopleton, Pinvin and Pershore. Local fords may also be flooded.   
River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours which may cause further rises in river levels.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated  by 17:00 today, 11/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Cambridgeshire, North Northamptonshire, Peterborough, West Northamptonshire

items.message: Over the last few days, we have seen heavy rainfall and snow in the River Nene area. This means that the River Nene has risen, which has lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river since yesterday. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outbuildings is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. But further rainfall is forecast for later on Saturday 11th March 2023 and over the next few days. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 09:00 on 12/03/23, or before if the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen on the River Thame and Chalgrove Brook as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and farmland is possible, especially in the Thame area. 
The forecast this morning is dry, with some outbreaks of rain this evening and overnight. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area clearing weed/trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 11/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
River levels are high but steady on the River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle due to rainfall.
Areas most at risk include the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole..
No property flooding is expected.
Flooding is possible at the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. from 11:00 AM on 10/03/2023.
Further light rainfall is forecast this this afternoon and evening.
River levels are high but steady, but the risk of flooding to roads remains.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 02:00 PM on 11/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Sutton Gault river gauge as a result of rapid snow melt and persistent rainfall in the upper catchment. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today, Saturday 11 March and is likely to continue into the next week. Flooding is affecting Hundred Foot Washes, also known as the Ouse Washes, including the causeways at Earith, Sutton Gault and Welney.
 
No rainfall is expected today, however further rain is forecast from tomorrow.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with Cambridgeshire County Council Highways, who will decide whether to close the road.

This information is correct as of 7:30 on Saturday 11 March 2023. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 20 centimetres of water on the road. There are currently no issues on the Welney or Earith causeways. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated this afternoon, 11/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Bishops Hull river gauge as a result persistent heavy rainfall and snowmelt.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible between noon on 09/03/2023 and 18:00 tomorrow, 10/03/2023.  We expect flooding to affect roads around Hillfarrance, Bradford on Tone, Lane End Road at Ham and the Creech St Michael to Henlade road. Bradford on Tone ringbanks will be bankfull.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further showery rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We expect river levels to rise until 10:00 on 10/03/2023.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking and clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated Friday, 10/03/2023 or as the situation changes

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Bradford on Avon gauge at Bradford on Avon  as a result of heavy rainfall and snow melt, with approximately 20mm of rain fallen in the last 48 hours. River levels on the River Avon at Great Somerford, River Avon at Bradford on Avon, River Avon at Bathford and Semington Brook at Semington are rising through this evening (the 09 March 2023). Currently we are not forecasting flood warning thresholds to be met. 

This message will be updated on Friday the 10th March 2023, or as the situation changes.

We expect flooding to effect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. We are closely monitoring the situation.

items.message:
River levels are high but steady as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding is affecting Roads close to the bridges at Harrold, Oakley, Felmersham and Radwell.
 
Further light rain is forecast for the next 24 hours.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

This message will be updated this afternoon, 11/03/23, or as the situation changes

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Saturday 11 March. River levels are beginning to drop in most areas, but will remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas, including Lordship Lane and Cow Watering Lane around Writtle College. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for no further rainfall during today. There is a small band of rain passing across this evening and another band of rain Sunday evening into Monday. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 5pm this evening, Saturday 11 March or as the situation changes.

River levels are continuing to fall at the Riseley river gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing. Flooding is affecting Riseley Brook from Riseley to Pertenhall.

Further light rain is forecast for the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

This message will be updated this afternoon, 11/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: Heavy rain and snow that fell across the River Nene catchment over the last few days has caused the River Nene levels to rise. During periods of high tide the River Nene will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding of the North Bank Road, between Peterborough and Rings End. Whilst this Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. This Flood Warning is expected to be in place for a few days, whilst river and tide levels remain high. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 19:00 on 11/03/23, or before, if the situation changes.

Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.62mAOD at 17:00 on 11/03/2023.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is high for this time of year at 160 cubic metres per second and is rising. We anticipate the flows to remain high for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 11/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message: The peak has passed and levels are now just below the flood risk thresholds. River levels will remain responsive to any further rainfall. The forecast is for no further rainfall during today. There is a small band of rain passing across this evening and another band of rain Sunday evening into Monday. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively monitoring river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.   
Stay aware in case further warnings are issued

River levels remain high but are falling at the Hamerton river gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing. Flooding is affecting Alconbury Brook at Hamerton, The Alconburys, Little Stukley and Brampton.

Further light rain is forecast for the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

This message will be updated this afternoon, 11/03/23, or as the situation changes.

The River Adur is high but now falling. Water could still affect fields and gardens near the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. Please take care if driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. Only small amounts of rain and isolated showers are forecast Friday, Saturday and Sunday, which will allow the river to fall towards a more normal level. Further persistent and heavy rain is forecast for Sunday evening 12/03/2023 and through Monday 13/03/2023. River levels are expected to rise again Monday 13/03/2023 and flood impacts could return. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will reissue this message if confidence in the risk of flooding increases.

Over the last few days, we have seen heavy rainfall and snow in the Harpers Brook and Willow Brook area. This means that Harpers Brook and Willow Brook have risen, which has lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river since yesterday. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outbuildings is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. But further rainfall is forecast for later on Saturday 11th March 2023 and over the next few days. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 09:00 on 12/03/23, or before if the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River East Glen, River West Glen, River Tham

Please avoid contact with flood water.

This message will be updated this afternoon, 11/03/23, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.
 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  
We continue to monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are clearing debris from weed screens.

items.description: River Rhee in Central Bedfordshire, Hertfordshire and Cambridgeshire
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Wimpole river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property/roads and farmland is possible today, 11/03/23.  Flooding is affecting River Rhee from Guilden Morden to Haslingfield.   
Further light rain is forecast for the next 24 hours. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated this afternoon, 11/03/23, or as the situation changes

items.description: River Ivel in Hertfordshire and Central Bedfordshire
items.message:
River levels are high but falling at the Shefford river gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing. Flooding is affecting River Ivel from Langford to Blunham, including the rivers Purwell, Hiz, Flit and Hit.
Further light rain is forecast for the next 24 hours.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated this afternoon, 11/03/23, or as the situation changes.

We continue to monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.

items.description: Upper River Cam in Essex and Cambridgeshire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Great Chesterford river gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing. Flooding is affecting River Cam from Newport to Whittlesford including the Slades.
Further light rain is forecast for the next 24 hours.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated this afternoon, 11/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Bure, Spixworth Beck and surrounding Becks
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. River levels will remain responsive to any further rainfall. The forecast is for no further rainfall during today. There is a small band of rain passing across this evening and another band of rain Sunday evening into Monday. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The upper Stour and surrounding tributaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Saturday 11 March. River levels remain high in some areas and will remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas around Haverhill, Clare and Sudbury, including Kedington, Sturmer, Steeple Bumpstead, Cavendish, Bridge Street and Long Melford. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for no further rainfall during today.  There is a small band of rain passing across this evening and another band of rain Sunday evening into Monday. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 5pm this evening, Saturday 11 March or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Granta in Essex and Cambridgeshire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling at the Linton river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing. Flooding is affecting River Granta from Linton to Babraham.
Further light rain is forecast for the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated this afternoon, 11/03/23, or as the situation changes

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Saturday 11 March. River levels are beginning to drop and remain above the threshold in some areas.  Levels will remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas on the Deben from Debenham to Ufford, including Framsden, Earl Soham, Easton, Glevering and Wickham Market, and on the Rivers Lark and Finn around Witnesham, Tuddenham St Martin, Playford and Grundisburgh. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for no further rainfall during today. There is a small band of rain passing across this evening and another band of rain Sunday evening into Monday. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 5pm this evening, Saturday 11 March or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Stour from Sudbury to Stratford St Mary and Dedham
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Saturday 11 March. River levels remain high in some areas and will remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas of the River Stour between Sudbury and Dedham. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for no further rainfall during today. There is a small band of rain passing across this evening and another band of rain Sunday evening into Monday. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 5pm this evening, Saturday 11 March or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high in some areas and will remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas around Halesworth, Wissett, Chediston, Walpole, Huntingfield, Bramfield and Wrentham. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for no further rainfall during today. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 5pm this evening, Saturday 11 March or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Stour area from Fordwich to Stonar Cut
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.. 

We continue to monitor the situation and will re issue any alerts or warnings if required.

items.description: The River Colne from Great Yeldham to Colchester
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Saturday 11 March. River levels remain high in some areas and will remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are properties around Bridge Street, North Road, and the High Street in Great Yeldham. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for no further rainfall during today. There is a small band of rain passing across this evening and another band of rain Sunday evening into Monday. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 5pm this evening, Saturday 11 March or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Rattlesden River and River Gipping, through and including Stowmarket and Needham Market
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. River levels will remain responsive to any further rainfall. The forecast is for no further rainfall during today. There is a small band of rain passing across this evening and another band of rain Sunday evening into Monday. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Over the last few days, we have seen heavy rainfall and snow in the River Nene area. This means that the River Nene has risen, which has lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river since yesterday. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outbuildings is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. But further rainfall is forecast for later on Saturday 11th March 2023 and over the next few days. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 09:00 on 12/03/23, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Ely Ouse in Cambridgeshire, Suffolk and Norfolk
items.message:
River levels remain high in the Bottisham Lode and Quy Water area as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding could affect Botisham Lode and Quy Water.

Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water. 
 
This message will be updated  this afternoon, 11/03/23, or as the situation changes.

Over the last few days, we have seen heavy rainfall and snow in the North Kesteven area. This means that the River Witham in North Kesteven has risen, which has lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river since yesterday. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outbuildings is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. But further rainfall is forecast for later on Saturday 11th March 2023 and over the next few days. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 09:00 on 12/03/23, or before if the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively monitoring river levels and the weather forecast. 
Please avoid contact with flood water and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.

Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. River levels will remain responsive to any further rainfall. The forecast is for no further rainfall during today. There is a small band of rain passing across this evening and another band of rain Sunday evening into Monday. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Brentingby Dam river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Mill Lane and Water Lane at Frisby on the Wreake, Station Road at Thrussington, Broome Lane at Ratcliffe on the Wreake, Frisby, farmlands at Hoby, Brooksby, Thrussington, Ratcliffe and Syston. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 17:00 this afternoon, 11/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the South Wigston river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding continues.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including the farmland in Great Glen, Kilby Bridge, South Wigston and Blaby as well as the road at Crow Mills. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 17:00 this afternoon, 11/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Leam at Eathorpe, Huningham and Offchurch
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Eathorpe river gauge as a result of rainfall and snow melt.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains but is reducing.  The peak for Eathorpe Gauge was 2.305m at 04:45 on Saturday morning 11/03/23.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. 
Please take photographs of any flood damage and avoid contact with flood water.
Stay aware in case further warnings are issued.
This message will be updated by 17:00 on 11/03/23, or as the situation changes.
